Instructions.text: Press the gray button written FEED to see the Feed graphs. The stream going from the mine to the flotation circuit is usually called FEED. It has a certain grade of valuable metal, in our case copper.
Look at the graph. What is the copper grade of this stream?
Well done. Considering it is your first time in this screen, what is the flow rate of the Feed Stream?
That's correct. Even if you have changed it, you could have guessed since flow rate is given by tons per hour.
What is the flow rate of Concentrate Stream (the one which goes from the flotation bank to the bin)? Make sure your Feed flow rate is at 10 t/h, the air is at 2 cm/s and froth is at -10 mm.

Correct. It means that from the 10 tons entering your flotation cell, 2 tons go to the Concentrate (which is the material that we can process and sell), while the other 8 tons go to the Tailings stream, which we didn't show for didactic purposes.
Now going back to the Concentrate, as a flotation operator you want to make sure you are producing the right amount of Concentrate according to your Feed flow rate.
After all, producing 6 tons of Concentrate out of 6 tons of Feed is very profitable, while producing 6 tons out of 600 hundred tons of Feed will make you bankrupt.
You can check if you are doing a good job by finding the CONCENTRATION RATIO. It represents the amount of tons you need to feed the cell in order to produce one ton of concentrate.
For example, if your concentrate flow rate is 1 t/h with a feed flow rate of 10 t/h, your concentration ratio is 10. The cell is producing one ton of concentrate with 10 tons of feed.

Now try this. Check the Concentrate graphs to make sure your Cu recovery is above 80%. Then find the Concentrate Ratio of this process.

 Concentration ratio =
Feed flow rate / Concentrate flow rate

Correct. Now open the FEED graphs and change the Feed flow rate to around 20. Did the concentration ratio change? 

 Concentration ratio =
Feed flow rate / Concentrate flow rate
Exactly! It is not uncommon for cells to be designed to work with an optimal Concentration Ratio. In the next lessons, we will learn about other performance calculations. Good job for now!
